questions.text: A 62-year-old male with a history of smoking presents with chronic cough, weight loss, and recent hemoptysis. A chest X-ray is done and is provided below. Which of the following is the most likely primary source of this lesion?

A 65-year-old male with a history of chronic liver disease presents with progressive shortness of breath, fatigue, and mild chest discomfort over the past few weeks. On examination, there is decreased bilateral breath sound intensity with dullness on percussion at the lung bases. A chest X-ray shows the following features. What is the most likely diagnosis?

options.label: D
options.text: Congestive Heart Failure with Pleural Effusion

questions.text: A 65-year-old man visits OPD with the following presentation as shown in the image. His chest CT shows bronchiectasis. Which of the following statements is INCORRECT regarding this patient's digital finding?

options.label: A
options.text: The condition involves proliferation of connective tissue at the nail base

options.label: B
options.text: It can be associated with cystic fibrosis and lung cancer

options.label: C
options.text: The condition always indicates irreversible tissue changes

options.label: D
options.text: The pathogenesis involves platelet-derived growth factors

questions.correct_answer: C. The condition always indicates irreversible tissue changes
questions.explanation:
Clubbing of Fingers

Definition

• Enlargement of distal segments of fingers and toes

• Proliferation of connective tissue (Option A)

• Particularly on dorsal surface

• Changes at base of clubbed nail

Pathophysiology

• Connective tissue proliferation

• Exact mechanism unknown

• Platelet-derived growth factors implicated (Option D)

Clinical Signs
  • Bulbous Enlargement of the Distal Phalanges
  • Loss of the Normal Angle Between the Nail and the Nailbed (Lovibond’s Angle)
  • Increased Sponginess of the Soft Tissue at the Base of the Nail
  • Nail Changes:
  • Nail flattening/nail curvature
  • Hippocratic fingers: The tips of the fingers become enlarged, and the nails curve downward

Clinical tests

Schamroth’s Sign:

  • Normal: A small diamond-shaped window should be visible between the nails when the fingers are positioned in this way.
  • Positive Schamroth’s Sign: The window disappears, and there is no gap between the nails, indicating the loss of the normal angle at the nail bed.

Associated Conditions

• Cyanotic congenital heart disease

• Infective endocarditis

• Bronchiectasis

• Cystic Fibrosis (Option B)

• Lung cancer

• Tuberculosis

• Inflammatory bowel disease

Key Features

• Can be hereditary or acquired

• May be reversible in certain circumstances

• Associated with hypertrophic osteoarthropathy

• Can cause pain and arthritis-like changes

questions.text: A 25-year-old male presents to the emergency department with sudden onset of right-sided chest pain and mild shortness of breath. He is tall, thin, and a smoker. Physical examination reveals decreased breath sounds on the right side with hyperresonance on percussion. Chest X-ray is given below. The patient is hemodynamically stable with oxygen saturation of 96% on room air. What is the most appropriate initial management?

options.label: D
options.text: High-flow oxygen and observation for 24 hours

questions.explanation:
Type

Clinical Features

Investigations

Management

Primary Spontaneous Pneumothorax (PSP)

• Young, tall, thin males

• Sharp chest pain

• Mild dyspnea

• Decreased breath sounds

• Hyperresonant percussion

• Chest X-ray

• CT scan (if needed)

• E-FAST ultrasound

• Size < 2cm, asymptomatic: Observation

• Size > 2cm or symptomatic: Needle aspiration

• Failed aspiration: Tube thoracostomy

• Recurrent: Consider VATS/pleurodesis

Secondary Spontaneous Pneumothorax (SSP)

• Underlying lung disease

• Severe dyspnea

• Significant chest pain

• Respiratory distress

• Higher risk of tension

• Chest X-ray

• CT scan (mandatory)

• ABG analysis

• Underlying disease workup

• Size < 1cm: O₂ + observation

• Size 1-2cm: Needle aspiration

• Size > 2cm: Tube thoracostomy

• All cases: Treat underlying condition

questions.text: A 28-year-old male is brought to the emergency department after a motor vehicle accident with chest trauma. He is in severe respiratory distress with BP 80/50 mmHg, HR 142/min, RR 32/min. Physical examination reveals absent breath sounds. The X-ray is attached below. What is the most appropriate next step in management?

options.label: A
options.text: CT Head for identifying possible cerebral injury

questions.explanation:
Tension Pneumothorax

Clinical features

• Severe respiratory distress

• Hypotension

• Tachycardia (>134 bpm)

• Tracheal deviation

• JVD

• Cyanosis

Investigations

• Clinical diagnosis

• Don't wait for imaging

• Post-procedure CXR

Management

• Immediate: Needle decompression

• Definitive: Tube thoracostomy

• Follow-up: Pleurodesis consideration

questions.text: A 68-year-old female receiving a blood transfusion for severe anemia develops acute dyspnea, tachypnea, and hypertension 30 minutes into the transfusion. Her blood pressure is 168/95 mmHg, and chest auscultation reveals bilateral crackles. Which of the following represents the most appropriate immediate management?

options.label: A
options.text: Continue transfusion but at a slower rate

questions.correct_answer: B. Stop transfusion and administer diuretics
questions.explanation:
Transfusion-Associated Circulatory Overload (TACO)

Definition

Common and underrecognized transfusion adverse reaction

Incidence

1-10% per RBC transfusion

Risk Factors

• Preexisting fluid overload

• Cardiac dysfunction

• Large volume of RBCs

• Excessive rate of transfusion

Clinical Features

• Dyspnea

• Hypertension

• Bilateral crackles

• Elevated brain natriuretic peptide

Prevention in High-Risk Patients

• Slow transfusion rate (RBCC over 3-4 h)

• Close monitoring

Management

• Stop transfusion

• Administer O2

• Give diuretics

questions.text: A 65-year-old male presents to the emergency department with acute dyspnea and bilateral crackles. His blood pressure is 160/90 mmHg, heart rate 110/min, and respiratory rate 28/min. Physical examination reveals jugular venous distention, bilateral pedal edema, and an S3 gallop. Chest X-ray is given below. His pulmonary capillary wedge pressure (PCWP) is 25 mmHg. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial management?
questions.explanation:
Features

Cardiogenic Pulmonary Edema

Non-cardiogenic Pulmonary Edema

Pathophysiology

• Increased hydrostatic pressure

• Left heart dysfunction

• PCWP >18 mmHg

• Increased capillary permeability

• Direct lung injury

• Normal PCWP (<18 mmHg)

Common Causes

• MI/CAD

• CHF

• Valvular heart disease

• Cardiomyopathy

• ARDS

• Sepsis

• Trauma

• Toxins/drugs

• High altitude

Clinical Features

• JVD present

• Peripheral edema

• S3 gallop

• Cardiomegaly on CXR

• No JVD

• No peripheral edema

• Normal heart sounds

• Normal heart size on CXR

Initial Management

• Diuretics (furosemide)

• Nitrates

• Proper positioning

• Oxygen support

• Treat underlying cause

• Supportive care

• Mechanical ventilation if needed

• No role for diuretics

questions.text: A 65-year-old male with a 40-pack-year smoking history presents with progressive dyspnea, productive cough, and weight loss. Physical examination reveals a barrel chest, decreased breath sounds, and prolonged expiration. Chest X-ray is given below. His FEV1/FVC ratio is 0.65 and doesn't improve with bronchodilators. Which of the following is the most likely pathological finding in this patient?

options.label: A
options.text: Inflammation of bronchial walls with mucus hypersecretion

options.label: B
options.text: Permanent enlargement of airspaces distal to terminal bronchioles

options.label: C
options.text: Bronchial wall thickening with reversible airway obstruction

questions.correct_answer: B. Permanent enlargement of airspaces distal to terminal bronchioles
questions.explanation:
Emphysema

Pathophysiology

• Destruction of alveolar walls

• Abnormal permanent enlargement of airspaces

• Elastase/anti-elastase imbalance

• Loss of elastic recoil

• Decreased gas exchange surface area

Causes

• Smoking (80-90% cases)

• Alpha-1 antitrypsin deficiency (1-2%)

• Environmental pollutants

• Biomass fuel exposure

• Occupational exposure

Clinical Features

• Progressive dyspnea

• Chronic cough

• Barrel chest

• Pursed-lip breathing

• Weight loss

• "Pink puffer" appearance

• Use of accessory muscles

Radiological Findings

• Hyperinflation

• Flattened diaphragm

• Increased lung volumes

• Tubular heart shadow

• Increased retrosternal airspace

Investigations

• Spirometry (FEV1/FVC < 0.7)

• Chest X-ray

• CT scan

• Alpha-1 antitrypsin levels

• Arterial blood gases

• DLCO (decreased)

Treatment

• Smoking cessation

• Bronchodilators (SABA, LABA)

• Anticholinergics (SAMA, LAMA)

• Inhaled corticosteroids

• Pulmonary rehabilitation

• Oxygen therapy if indicated

• Surgery in selected cases

• Vaccinations (influenza, pneumococcal)

questions.text: A 55-year-old man with a history of deep vein thrombosis is brought to the emergency department by his wife after he suddenly developed sharp, stabbing chest pain and shortness of breath while at home. He describes the pain as worse when taking a deep breath. The X-ray taken is displayed below. What is the most likely diagnosis?

options.label: C
options.text: Pulmonary infarction due to pulmonary embolism

questions.correct_answer: C. Pulmonary infarction due to pulmonary embolism
questions.explanation:
Pneumonia

Pneumonia (Option A), is incorrect as pneumonia usually presents on X-ray as a patchy or lobar consolidation, often not triangular or pleural-based. Pneumonia can be found in any lobe but is not typically wedge-shaped with an apex pointing toward the hilum.
 

Atelectasis

Atelectasis (Option B), is incorrect as atelectasis usually presents on X-ray as linear or wedge-shaped opacities but tends to involve volume loss or shifting of adjacent structures, such as the trachea or mediastinum, toward the affected area.
 

Lung abscess

Lung Abscess (Option D), is incorrect as a lung abscess usually presents on x-ray as a localized cavity with an air-fluid level if communicating with an airway. Abscesses are usually round or irregular in shape, not wedge-shaped or pleural-based like Hampton’s Hump.

questions.text: A 65-year-old male patient presents to the pulmonary clinic with a history of progressive shortness of breath and a chronic cough. He is a long-term smoker and has a family history of respiratory diseases. A spirometry test is performed, and the flow-volume loop is plotted. What is the most likely diagnosis based on the patient’s symptoms and the shape of his flow-volume loop?
questions.explanation:
Loop Type

Expiratory Curve

Inspiratory Curve

Example Conditions

Normal

Symmetrical, peaked

Symmetrical, rounded

Healthy lungs (Option C ruled out)

Obstructive

Scooped (concave)

Normal

COPD, asthma

Restrictive

Narrow, peaked

Narrow, peaked

Pulmonary fibrosis, pleural effusion (Option A ruled out)

Fixed Upper Airway Obstruction

Flattened (box-like)

Flattened (box-like)

Tracheal stenosis, large goiter (Option D ruled out)

Variable Extrathoracic Obstruction

Normal

Flattened

Vocal cord dysfunction, laryngeal tumor

Variable Intrathoracic Obstruction

Flattened

Normal

Tracheomalacia, bronchogenic tumor

questions.text: Match the Condition with the Correct Description on X-ray: 1. Pneumatocele a. 2. Tuberculosis (TB) b. 3. Miliary TB c. 4. Lung Abscess d.
